headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Maher Predicts "If It's Biden Against Trump, Biden Will Win"; Maher: "I Would Categorize Liberal As Different Than Woke"; Bill Maher: "I Am Afraid Of Trump On A Very Personal Level." Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Would you welcome please Bill Maher?TAPPER (voice-over): His decades, at the crossroads, of politics and comedy, has given him, an insight, political consultants and bookies would die for. From this, in 2015?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: All those people, who say "Donald Trump could not go all the way," I don't think they're right.TAPPER (voice-over): To this, just a few years later.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I don't think he's leaving, if - even if he loses the election in 2020.TAPPER (voice-over): Tonight, Bill Maher looks ahead to 2024, and Trump's odds now. TAPPER (on camera): You think he's going to get the nomination? And do you think he can beat Joe Biden? TAPPER (voice-over): And Maher doesn't hold back about President Biden or the Democrats either.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Democrats sometimes can take it too far.TAPPER (voice-over): He gives us his unfiltered take. TAPPER (on camera): How do you define wokeness? TAPPER (voice-over): On cancel culture, religion, and one of his favorite hobbies. TAPPER (on camera): So, you're a - you're a connoisseur of weed, I think that's very fair, to say.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I would think it's very fair.TAPPER (voice-over): From "Real Time" to PRIMETIME, this is a CNN One- On-One Special. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Welcome to a CNN PRIMETIME Special, ONE-ON-ONE WITH BILL MAHER.I'm Jake Tapper, in Washington, back from a sit-down, with a man, who isn't afraid to take on, well, anything. Bill Maher has been a figure in the world of political comedy for more than 40 years. And he doesn't seem to care who is in power or whether his opinion's unpopular. He still hits the road for stand-up shows across the country. And he's currently the Host of "Real Time with Bill Maher" on HBO, which like CNN is owned by Warner Brothers Discovery. This hour, you'll hear Maher's takes on the next race for the White House, the state of comedy and, what he calls, cancel culture. But first, we talked about how he got started in comedy, and how he has become the great predictor of Donald Trump. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So thanks so much for doing this.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Hey, pleasure.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So a lot of people might not know that your dad was actually in the news biz.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I mean, your mom was a nurse, but your dad was in the news business.And I'm - and I'm wondering how much you think that might have had an effect on the fact that you do very news-oriented comedy.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Tremendously. I think it was a great advantage.First of all, he was also funny. And you'll find this a lot with comedians that comedy gene sort of gestates through a generation. I grew up in a house that was interested in the news. My parents talked about the news. I was aware of it, in a way I don't think most kids were. So, those were my influences, comedy and news. And then what did I do? I wound up doing a show that is a comedy show that uses the news as fodder. And I wish my father could have lived to see it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: He pass away early?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No, but he - he saw me, like, do Johnny Carson, but he didn't see "Politically Incorrect."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What's your response when people tell you that - and you must hear this a lot - that they get - that you're one of their primary sources of information?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Flattered and, "as it should be" (LAUGH) is my response. I feel like people are looking for something that is not slanted.I mean, I certainly have lost fans, over the years, because I don't say the things that please people all the time. But that's my ultimate bond with the audience. When I lose people, it's, like, "OK, well, you were never meant to be with me in the first place." (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: We can't have a relationship.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There are a whole lot of people who are just conditioned to only hearing, only wanting to hear one side of the story.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Correct. They do not want to hear the other side. I mean, that's - it's so ironic. (COUGH) When I started on "Politically Incorrect" 30 years ago, 1993, everybody said, "You know, you can't really do a show like this because you're giving your opinions. That's not what talk show hosts do. They don't and can't give their opinions. You'll alienate half the crowd." (THROAT CLEAR)That's not what Johnny Carson did. That's not what David Letterman did. That's not what Jay Leno did. And I said, "Well, let's give it a try."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, it's brutal, but if I can find somebody better, that's what I'm doing. I always serve the show first.So every year, I read these packets of proposed writers, and I read them this year, as I do every year. And it's just stunning, how uniform their points of view are.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And it always - it hasn't always been that way?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Exact - I don't remember, but I don't think it was ever quite this bad. It's the exact same point of view on every single issue. And it's very predictable.I have a relationship with people who want to hear what I think is the truth. And I'm going to present both sides. And they may not be fair and balanced, there may not be equal weight put to each side, because that's not what the truth is. The truth isn't always 50/50.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: So - I live with that. But it's - it gets more difficult because we are so tribal now.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So it's interesting about this is because this comes after, five, six years of - of Trump, where it's not like you pulled punches against him at all.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No. Nobody was harder (LAUGH) on that man, I don't think. And honestly, nobody was more - had their hair on fire about what was going to happen, as far as him not believing in democracy and not wanting to leave.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I don't think he's leaving, if - even if he loses the election in 2020.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He could lose by a landslide in 2020. And I still think he would say "It's rigged. Fake news! Deep State!"

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: If Trump loses the election in November, he's not going to leave.(AUDIENCE LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You were predicting that in 2018? MAHER

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: 2016, you're saying he's--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, before he was even president, I said, this--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: He's not going to leave if he loses?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Never going to leave, right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And I--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What made you think that?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: (LAUGH) Have you seen this man? He's everything wrong with a human being stuffed into one man. I mean, how could he ever do anything different?He is incapable, I think, of ever conceding defeat, and I've never seen him do it. So, why would I think he would be gracious ever, in that situation, or say he ever lost? And he said it. I mean, even in 2016 when he was running, they would ask him point-blank, "Would you--" "Well-- it's--" you know, he's basically saying, "If we win, yes, then it's a fair election. If we don't, it was rigged." He would never actually just come out and say, "Yes, of course, this is America. This is how we do."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: "This is the jewel in our crown in this country. We - the peaceful transfer of power." Nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You've been the great predictor of Donald Trump. You thought he could win. You thought he wasn't going to--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --leave peacefully.He's running.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You think he's going to get the nomination? And do you think he can beat Joe Biden?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Both.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But both you think affirmatively? Or both think - you think they - they could happen?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I - I - well, first of all, it could - it might not be Joe Biden. I think if it's Biden against Trump, Biden will win. I do. Not guaranteed, but I think that's a really good bet. It was the first time, and I think it would be the second time even more so.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Even at age 82?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.Well, first of all, I think that's a big red herring that his age is such a factor. You don't need to be young or spry to be president. Yes, it's very helpful to run for president. You need to be energetic and look sharp at the debate. He could do the job of president perfectly fine, and I think he's done the job perfectly fine. Do I love everything he has done? Absolutely not. But he's president. That goes with the territory. But generally, he's restored normality. He's got some things passed that nobody thought he could get through this divided Congress. Got out of Afghanistan. Did he stick the landing on that one? No, but at least he did it. I mean, Ukraine? I think he's done fine. And every other country in the world seems to have gotten this idea about the elderly: "They're wise." That's what you need. I don't mind at all that he's 82 or 84 or 86. Yes, if he loses his marbles, but there are plenty of 86-year-old people who have not lost their marbles. And people used to get that. "We have an important decision to make." "Go to the elders. They will tell you what the wise decision is," and then you young people will go and carry it out. He doesn't have to go and do every little thing. I mean, Reagan didn't do anything! He went to bed at 4:30! So that does not bother me at all. No, it's going to bother people in the country, because when you run for president, you get exposed, your flaws. And yes, he's - when you're in your 80s, he's going to stumble. He was always a gaffe machine to begin with.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: So, it could look bad. But I think as, if it's Trump against Biden, I think Biden will win. But - if it--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What if it's not Biden--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: --if it's not Biden, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I support it in fact. But, I mean, the Democrats sometimes can take it too far. Or I would - I would categorize liberal as different than woke.Woke, which started out as a good thing, alert to injustice. Who could be against that? But it became sort of an eye-roll, because they love diversity except of ideas. And that's not really where we should be. I mean, they have a trail of very bad ideas, I would think, in wokeness. Like--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: How do you define wokeness? Because I hear people use the term all the time, and they mean something different to everybody.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, again, I think it's this collection of ideas that are not building on liberalism but very often undoing it.I mean, five years ago, I don't - Abraham Lincoln was not a controversial figure among liberals. We liked him. (LAUGH) Now they take his name off schools and tear down his statues. Really? Lincoln isn't good enough for you? Five, 10 years ago - bedrock liberalism was, we are striving to be a color-blind society, where we don't see race. Of course, we see it, but it doesn't matter. That's not what woke is. Woke is something very different. It's - it's identity pol-- it's we see it all the time. It's always the most important thing. I don't think that's liberalism. I mean, I could mention so many issues like that. I remember doing - that show on HBO, "Comic Relief" for the homeless. And the idea then - again, among liberals, I thought was, "For the sake of compassion, can we get these people off the street so they have a roof over their heads?" And now it's, like, "How dare you (LAUGH) try to move the homeless. This is where they live." It's, like - again, you change the definitions, and then you say I am more conservative? I believe what I've always believed. You change these things, and then you yell at me for it. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Up next, he got it right in 2016 and 2020. What's Bill Maher's take on Trump 2024?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It's not me who's changed. It's the left, who is now made up of a small contingent who've gone mental, and a large contingent, who refuse to call them out for it. But I will.(END VIDEO CLIP) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Do you think Democratic politicians have changed their views? Or do you think they're just afraid of their party's activists the way that a lot of Republicans are afraid of their party's activists, the MAGA folks?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: B. (LAUGH) They're afraid, yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: They're just afraid?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think - I think both sides, I think, again, there's four tribes, I think, in this country. I think there's old-school liberals and old-school conservatives, Republicans and Democrats, the kind of people who used to - I think that's the majority of the country.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Like Hillary Clinton and Jeb Bush or something?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. The kind of people who never agreed on a hell of a lot, but they found ways to work together. They didn't hate each other.It wasn't all about making liberal tears and cry and all this stuff, and, owning and destroying people. It was just, "Yes, I don't agree with Bob Dole, but, we can work together. We can get a grand bargain." That kind of stuff. And so I think that's the majority. But then you have Trumpers and then you have wokesters. And those fringes are not doing this country any great favors.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: If Donald Trump is challenged for the nomination - I mean, he's obviously already being challenged by Governor Nikki Haley, and then there's talk of other people.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Governor DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And Mike Pompeo and others, Vice President Pence. Do you think any of them can take him out?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No. But I think what they will do is ensure him the nomination.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: By splitting all the alternates? MAHER

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Same thing that happened before?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. The only way Trump doesn't get that nomination is if it's just him and DeSantis.If it's a bunch of people in there, yes, they're going to split the anti-Trump vote, because, Trump has a very hard-core following. I mean, it's a cult. And cults don't ever go away. Look at Christianity! So, I despair about that, because I think when politicians smell the White House, they don't care about the repercussions for the country. They just want to go for it. DeSantis against Trump, I think, could get it. Somebody said to me once, a conservative guy, he said, "The thing you guys don't understand about us is we don't really like Trump." Now that doesn't speak for all the Trumpers. He definitely has some real fans.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oh sure.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: But there's a lot of people who voted for him, and that's their little secret, "We don't like him either. We just vote for him because the stuff that you guys are doing on your fringe is scarier to us than what he's doing," which is saying a lot. And I'm not quite with them, but I get it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I get it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I think it's also that he hates the same people that they hate, even if they don't agree with Trump--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And they love it that he sticks his thumb in their eye.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.Do you think that DeSantis is part of the old-school Republican tribe? Or do you think he's more of a Trumper 2.0?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: (LAUGH).

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I mean, I don't think that's going to hold Ron DeSantis back.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You know, it's interesting, I met this couple from Florida, liberal Democrats, and then they told how much they loved Ron DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Loved him. And it's for the governance.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: From Florida?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. They were from Florida.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: The people in Florida like him.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, he won reelection with almost 60 percent of the vote.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Also, while the rest of the country was overdoing COVID, Flor-- I was there during COVID. It was night and day from this place. And I am not one who is ever on the page with COVID paranoia. So, I thought it was a breath of fresh air.And the people there, when they would visit me here sometimes they would say, "Oh my God." In the middle of the pandemic, what - what do you-- "Do you people live like this? It's so unnecessary. We don't live like this."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And it turned out a lot of what Ron DeSantis did was smarter than what the people who were criticizing were saying. I mean, he kept the beaches open.Yes, you're not going to get it outside. In fact, it's good. Get some fresh air and some sunshine. That would be better for you. And he also protected the elderly. It was much more targeted. It was sort of the opposite of what happened in New York State. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Next, he is an outspoken critic of what he calls cancel culture. But as someone with a history of controversial comments himself, does Bill Maher think his clock is ticking?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: The oath of office, I took, was to comedy.(AUDIENCE LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And if you do goofy shit, wherever you are in the spectrum, I'm going to make fun of you because that's where the gold is.(END VIDEO CLIP) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What is it like to be a comedian in this era? Is it more difficult?Do audiences boo you at times that you're not ready for them to boo you or you're surprised?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It's always possible. I mean, it's interesting. My studio audience at "Real Time" (LAUGH) always booed me - not - for most of the show, but they were definitely more woke than I was - and definitely more sensitive.I would ask all - all the time over there, I said, "Why? These are the people who - they claim that they - flew all the way across the country. They waited for months to get tickets to this show. They're my fans. And then they come here and they're saying, 'Oh.'" There's something about when you get in public you have to put on this act that you are somehow more of a moral person than you really are. Not that I'm doing anything immoral, but that you have to react in a certain way to things that are politically incorrect. You'd think I would come pre-advertised. I mean, there's a sign right--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right, "Politically Incorrect." MAHERAnd then, about five years ago we did - I don't know what they did with the audience but they - they got rid of the groaners, and it made my life so much better. And there are people who actually say to me now, "Oh, I miss the days when you used to fight with the audience."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: (LAUGH).

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, maybe you do, but I don't.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: You know? But I was never one of those comics, who could just pretend, "Oh, (LAUGH) I'm sorry. I must've made a mistake there."I'd be like, "No, I didn't make a mistake. There's nothing wrong with that joke. Stop groaning. Get the stick out of your ass." I must've said that 20 times on my show.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And then when the pandemic came around, first we didn't have any audience, then we shot here.And when we came back we were allowed to have, like, half the audience because of social distancing. And again, they just weeded out the people who were groaning. And I would say in the last three, four years I've never had that problem again, and it is such a pleasure. My audience who comes to my show now understands me. They think like me. They - they have open minds. They're - they're not woke. They're generally liberal, but they can be conservative too. And we have a great time, and there's no groaning. And I love it. And on the road it was always that way. People who pay, you know, a good penny for a hard ticket price to come see a stand-up show, they generally want you to be exactly who you are. So it's - it was always pretty hard to get - I'd have to be (LAUGH) pretty far out there, I could do it, to get people to groan on the road. But, look, any comic in this era, anybody in this era can absolutely fall off the ledge at any moment. It's - it just makes me laugh when people say to me, "You know, you're uncancelable." Are you kidding? I could - I would - in two seconds, I could get canceled. Anybody could.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Who were the comedians that influenced you, that-- that encouraged you to walk towards this path where you're not afraid to say what you think?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Carlin was the main one who did that, in the era, when I was growing up and when thinking about being a comedian, when I was a kid. He was the guy who, when I was really little, he was, just a suit and tie, short haircut, doing funny stuff.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: But not controversial.And then he had that big turnaround around 1970 - when I was 14. So, this was very formative, for me. I already knew I wanted to be a comedian. And so, to see a guy do that, suddenly he had long hair, and he was wearing a t-shirt. And he was challenging the Establishment, and he was saying bold things. And he did that for the rest of his life. I didn't always even agree with him. He said some really weird things. He was not an environmentalist, for example.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: But he never pulled a punch. And he - you know, I remember (LAUGH) one special, his first - his opening line - I can't say the word, but it's the word that begins with F, and it was, "F (LAUGH) Lance Armstrong." And this was when Lance Armstrong was the biggest hero--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Before he was--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: This--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --uncovered, yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: This - this was before the fall.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And just to say that's his opening line. But he said, "Don't tell me who my heroes are. (LAUGH) Don't tell me who my heroes are supposed to be. Don't dictate that to me."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I loved that. And I like Lance Armstrong (LAUGH).

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Did - did you - you - you must've met Carlin a million times.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I met him a few times. He was on the show - my old show a couple of times. It really wasn't for him. I understood why. It was - you had to share the stage with three other people, and they were not up to his intellectual caliber. So - he didn't do that a lot.I mean, we - we were not contemporaries, so I did not really know him at all. But I did speak at his memorial, and I was proud to be there.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, I hear a lot about comedians being afraid to perform in the new environment, but by the same token, I mean, I see Dave Chappelle still doing very well. MAHER

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There's one thing I - I wanted to get your reaction to something because obviously Chappelle has been criticized a lot because of his - making fun of transgender-- the transgender community.This is what David Cross says, and he's - David Cross is a pretty edgy comedian and--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, great - great comedian.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And he says - this is - he's talking - he's not talking about you certainly, and he's not even talking about Chappelle necessarily, in the quote, but he's talking about people who make the kind of jokes, making fun of transgender.He said, "You're positioning yourself as this bullshit voice of, 'They're not going to cancel me. You can't silence me.' For what? Your dumb joke about trans people? Who gives a shit? I mean, is it that important to you? Just move on and not hurt hundreds of thousands of people. It's a choice people make." I thought that was an interesting quote. What did - I mean, I guess the larger criticism of Chappelle, from people, like David Cross is he's punching down, not like what Carlin did punching up. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I don't really agree. I mean, I think the trans community is asking for too much.Again, the difference between liberal and woke. Liberals are people who I think would say - I certainly would-- trans is, of course, a real thing. Some people are just, I don't - I'm - they probably don't like this terminology, but born in the wrong body, whatever the - (LAUGH) the equipment doesn't match how you feel. Absolutely. And it's great we live in a time where people like that can freely live the lives they should live with all the dignity and protection of the law that we can afford them, like anybody else in society. I think that's the liberal point of view. The woke point of view is something very different, like "Well, babies are born now, and just jump ball, we don't know what they are." "Congratulations, you have a boy." "Well, let's not be hasty. There's a penis. That could be an indication of a male, but it's - (LAUGH) it's really-- we'll find out later. And we can always get rid of it." And it's not wrong to have this discussion. This is some - something that's very new.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It's not to shut it - to shut down debate with these words like "Phobia." "You're phobic, and you hate" - we don't hate. There's not hate. It's not phobic. We're not afraid.We're just discussing something very new that involves children and what - these interventions you're making have repercussions for the entire rest of their lives, and they're about their health, which I think should come first.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, I think if a trans activist were here, right now, they might say, "We're not afraid of having discussions and debate. But you're talking about these issues at a time when states like (COUGH) Idaho and Florida and others are talking about banning these procedures, regardless of what the kid and the parents and the doctor want."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, that's a--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And that that's, like, a bigger issue than the term, "Pregnant people."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, that's probably a backlash that went too far.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You think that's--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think that is, to - to completely ban it.But I also - I also don't agree with what you just said. They absolutely do want to shut down debate. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Next on CNN PRIMETIME, he's given million-dollar political donations, in the past. So, will Bill Maher open his wallet again?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Instead of giving an "I Voted" sticker to the people who did vote, let's make the people who didn't vote wear one that says "I Couldn't Be Bothered".(END VIDEO CLIP) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The way you talk, I wonder if you are going to be as involved politically in 2024 as you have been in the past. I remember you giving millions of dollars - to help Barack Obama--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --get elected.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I - well, I gave - I gave a million dollars to Obama. That - one I'm absolutely happy--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: --happy I did that. Yes. Because it was the first year of the Citizens United ruling went into effect.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right. So, you gave it to Priorities USA, which is a pro- Obama--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --super PAC.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Correct. Because I felt like at the moment, people had not gotten the memo that we are playing on a completely different field than we ever were before. Anybody can give any amount of money. And somebody has to, like, ring the bell here and say, "Look, we're at the million-dollar level."I remember my manager saying, "Couldn't you just give $500,000?" (LAUGH) And I said, "No," because the million - million dollars gets people's attention.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Especially from somebody who's not a billionaire. A million dollars hurt. I - I wasn't driving an Uber. But it hurt, OK? But I thought it was so important that the first Black president get reelected, almost more important than being elected. He could not be a one - and he was a good president.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So it wasn't--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It was not about Mitt Romney. I mean, I wasn't a big fan of Mitt Romney, but Mitt Romney wasn't - I would give anything for Mitt Romney to have been president instead of Donald Trump.But, no, it was about we have to make sure that the first Black president gets a fair shake and gets reelected. Otherwise people would've said, "Oh, see? We tried a Black president and it didn't work." And he was such the perfect first Black president, and I think one of our greatest presidents. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. Did a hell of a job in this office.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Thank you.(AUDIENCE APPLAUSE & CHEERS) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: So that was - yes. And then I gave - Chuck Schumer came around in 2018, and said, "I think I can retake the Senate, if you give me a million dollars. (LAUGH) And I know you've done it before."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And I did it again. That one I might want back because (LAUGH) it - it - first of all, it didn't work.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And, I - yes. So, now, of course every Democratic politician is always calling me up, and like, "Hey, you're - you're the easy"--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: "You're the million-dollar guy."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: --"You're the easy touch." (LAUGHTER) And it's like, "No, I think I'm done with my"--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Obama didn't even ask you if you'd give a million dollars! (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Are you - are you going to get involved? I mean, do you think it's important for a Democrat--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It's possible.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --to be in the White House and for the Democrats to control the Senate? What do you think of the Republican-led House?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: If it's - if it's Trump running - the problem is that I don't think money works anymore. I don't think it matters.I mean, Trump beat Hillary, and spent way less than she did.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He just was smarter. He didn't saturate the airwaves with commercials, like she did. And I think - I've been in markets - when I'm on the road doing stand- up where I'm in a hotel for literally 18 hours, and I see the same commercial 50 times. And by the time - I don't know even who this candidate is and I hate them!(LAUGH) It can work the other way around.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Trump saved all his money and he put on this great commercial, this hour-long commercial, like, the day before the election. That was very effective, and people saw that and--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It was a lot of Facebook ads. They did a lot of internet stuff.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. And of course he was also this guy that America had come to think of as this genius businessman because he was on "The Apprentice."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And I can't even go into it.But, look, it - if it was-- if I thought a million dollars could stop Donald Trump from being president again, yes, I - I would write - get out my checkbook again.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Were you despondent when Trump was elected? Did you think, "Oh, my God, this isn't the country I thought it was"?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I was - I was afraid for my own wellbeing. I thought I could wind up in Guantanamo Bay. I think I still could.I mean, he's - he was ranting about me all last week again. He's obsessed, sometimes. I don't know. He went on a tear for about eight months when he was president, every time he'd have a rally. I have a list, three pages long of the things he's called me. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Bill Maher, right? Everybody know Bill Maher, for example?(AUDIENCE BOO)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He's a radical-left maniac with modest television ratings, eh? Modest.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: "The press nut-job, low-rating sleaze-bag," and he was doing it again, last week. He doesn't--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: He did that (ph).

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He doesn't like that I'm on CNN.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I don't know why that gets to him. He doesn't like--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oh, he's doing it now--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He's doing it now!

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --since you started doing the thing on Friday nights.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. He's - he doesn't like that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: On Truth Social, he does it.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Or in a rally.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He doesn't like that Fox quotes me, when Fox quotes me.And, of course, Fox will watch one of my shows. 90 percent of it might be something they - material that they hate. But they take out of it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: No, they do the, "Even liberal Bill Maher." They - they just (LAUGH)--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right, exactly. You have to--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That's what they do to you every time.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right. You have to preface it by saying, "Look, we hate this guy. He's awful. But, you know, he said one good thing." And Trump, that drives - so I don't know.So, I - I am afraid of Trump on a very personal level, because I don't think he likes me. I understand why. And I don't know what he would do in a second term. I mean, he is obviously someone, who does not know any boundaries, and, you have to worry, when you see what other authoritarian rulers do, in other countries, to people. I'm not thinking he's going to become Putin, and start pushing people out windows, but I'm not going to live on the 30th floor anywhere either. (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Why do you think he obsesses about you so much?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I - I just--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Do you think he longs for your approval? Do you--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I - no. (LAUGH) I do - I cannot get into his head. I just think he - he lives - he's a media creature. He doesn't read. He only looks at television. I mean, every time he quotes me, he always says, "I was watching the show accidentally." (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right. It's--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I mean, if he only knew--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: "I just stumbled on HBO. (LAUGHTER) I don't know how that happened."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He's not aware of what a preposterous figure he is.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Ahead on this CNN PRIMETIME Special.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: You can believe in the Spaghetti Monster. You can believe in whatever god you want, whatever myth you want. We don't care. We just want to be left alone, and not castigated.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: God is a super-powerful. He could do anything.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Why doesn't he just obliterate the devil and therefore get rid of evil in the world?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He will.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: He will?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: What's he waiting for?(END VIDEO CLIP) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I know you're not a religious guy. In fact, you're (LAUGH) - you're an aggressive atheist.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No, not aggressive. I've used it for comedy fodder, certainly. I made one, I think, really good movie in my life called "Religulous" which was very funny and not mean-spirited about religion. But, atheists, I - I think that the idea that we are somehow aggressive or that we want to proselytize? That's what religion does. We're the opposite. We don't care. We don't care.You believe whatever you want to believe. You can believe in the Spaghetti Monster. You can believe in whatever god you want, whatever myth you want. We don't care. We just want to be left alone, and not castigated for it. And I would like a little representation. I mean, the Supreme Court is now six and a half Catholics, OK?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Who's the half?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think there are more than that.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: That - not - that they would say it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Well, that's like saying, like, in the 1950 House, there were no gay people. Yes, there were.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: They just weren't out. (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: They'd be thrown out with--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I mean, I have a sneaky feeling Obama is not really a super- Christian, like he said. He used to say, "Well, the first thing in the morning, I get a scripture on my Blackberry." Really?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, somebody sent it to him, that's for sure--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Somebody sent it to him, OK. Well - yes. I'd - I mean, he - you know, he said, my mother was a humanist. I think that - wink, wink, "humanist." (LAUGH)I mean, look - you're--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Your dad was Catholic, your mom was Jewish.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was raised Catholic.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. MAHER

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, the only reason - when I say - I mean, I - agnosticism makes more sense to me, the idea of like, "Look, I have no idea." That makes more sense to me than atheism.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: It's the - it's the same thing almost. I mean, you're--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Atheism is, "There's nothing there."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No. No.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: "It's all a ruse."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No, no, you're wrong.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: No?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Atheism means a-theism.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: "I have no beliefs."

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In terms of god?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: The-ism?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do believe in God (ph).

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: --is the belief in a god.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I preach the Gospel of "I don't know." I don't - anything--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well but that's more - that's agnostic is what that is.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Again, you're splitting hairs. You're just - (LAUGH) you're just-- you're getting hung up on the terms. Even Richard Dawkins, the famous atheist--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: --says, on a scale of one to seven, where seven would be total certainty that there is no god, I'm a 6.9, because we don't know.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Because there are - there are so many questions we can't answer, of course. And I allow for that.I mean, I - of course, we can't - but the - but what an atheist says is, "Yes, there are questions we can't answer like, 'How did we get here?' But what we don't do is make up stories to say how we got here."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: All of this is just a preface for me to say (LAUGH) if your dad is out there somewhere watching this, I think he would be happy about you being on CNN. I think he (LAUGH)--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --I think he would. As a newsman, he would say, that's nice, that they're--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: You mean if he's watching over--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Whatever, I don't know how it works.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: We don't know how it works. But I doubt it's that. (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We don't know.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: We don't know - exactly.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: It's nice to think.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right. A 6.9.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right. But it doesn't make any sense for it just to be like we're here and then we're not, and then it's all just, "Poof." To me, it doesn't make any sense.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: But it seems to be the case. (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There's no evidence to the contrary, but that--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --doesn't mean that this seems to be the case.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Correct. And that's--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But if we only use 10 percent of our brains?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There's a whole 90 percent that we don't even know what's going on.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: But, when you're dead, your brain's gone. It's being eaten by worms. So, I wouldn't count on that.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: After the break, forget politics, comedy, and live shows. Bill Maher reflects on one of his favorite hobbies. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, you're a connoisseur of weed I think that's fair to say.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: You know, not a week goes by without someone asking me to get into the pot business with them. "Don't get left behind," they tell me. We can make a fortune selling Maherijuna or Billy Buds or Silly Billy's Wacky Tobacky (ph).(AUDIENCE LAUGHTER) (END VIDEO CLIP) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So you're a - you're a connoisseur of weed, I think that's fair to say.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I would think it's very fair.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So what's the best (LAUGH) weed you've ever smoked?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Interesting you say that. It was - I can answer that question. It was Acapulco Gold, and I've never seen it since. It was - I was in college and I remember it came in a brick, like a brick, like it was--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: This is in Ithaca, New York, at Cornell?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Ithaca, New York, yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You got a brick of--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --Acapulco Gold?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, you know - (LAUGH) at Cornell, that's how I got through Cornell, by - (LAUGH) by - I mean, I was selling it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Those are--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: You know, there was--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --those are cold winters in - in Ithaca.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I would never have gotten through college without that - you know, money-wise. But--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oh, selling it, you mean?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes. (LAUGH) I was a - let's just say I was ahead of my time because it's legal now.But it was this - it was, like, pressed into this brick, and it was gold. I've never seen pot that looked that way, and I never had a high like that, and I've never seen it again. But if anybody out there (LAUGH) wants to turn me in the right direction, it'd be enormously appreciated. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But it wasn't all smoke at the bar. I also wanted to know who he looks up to most, his inspiration. And I was surprised by his answer.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Who is your hero, other than Ben Carlin? Who is your hero? Who is somebody that you really admire and look up to?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: George Washington.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Seriously?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: (LAUGH) Yes. Why - why is that even--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, because it seems like a very earnest answer. It seems--

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I know. But why would - it's so funny that--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Because you're Bill Maher to nod back (ph) to George Washington--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: No, but now that he's like sort of semi-canceled too, you know? It's another thing--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That's not what I meant it. I just meant it.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I know. But it's--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But I didn't expect you to - like, if you had said Rutherford B. Hayes, I would've been surprised too. I mean, like, I just - I wasn't expecting - I was expecting, somebody in the world of - that you live.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You know?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Oh. I see.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I mean, you know?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: I would've been more surprised by Bob Hope than George Washington, I suppose.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Bob Hope was not a good guy.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: No, no. I know. (LAUGH) That's why I'm saying - that's - that's why I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: I mean, when I was a kid, it wasn't George Washington. It was like Johnny Carson. That's who I wanted to be. I wanted to be Johnny Carson and James Bond.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Why George Washington now?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know if you heard, but he's the father of the country.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right now - and he was a great general also.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: And--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Also the willingness to only do two terms, is that it?

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Exact - well, that--

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MAHER
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, leading the Rev - keeping the country alive. And he only fought when he was the general in the Revolution. He only fought nine battles. And he only won three.He understood that he's not going to beat that British army. He just had to keep the army existing. He just had to keep them alive. So, he was always running away. And also, yes, then gave up the crown when he could - could've gone the other way. And also the - he was so prescient. He's the one who said political parties are going to be the death of us. Once we get into that kind of factional thinking - and look at all these years later, that's really how it turned out. (END VIDEOTAPE)
